moves.1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 c5: Tarrasch, open variation till now, where I make an out-of-place move, letting black develop his pieces.
A blunder by me. I should've played for castling first, as the rook will be dangerous on the open e-file.
moves.8... O-O 9. Bxf6: Another blunder by white, trying to earn a pawn, totally ignoring the e-file attack.
My castling is now broken, and black has a great advantage.
moves.12... Nd7 13. Ng5 Nf6: 13 ...  Qf6 is superior, with the mate-threat on f2.
moves.14. Qxf7+ Kh8 15. Qc4 g6 16. Nf7+ Kg7 17:
I passively defend the rook at a1, against Bxb3.
19 ... Rf8! is the strong move, since the attack after Ng4 is unavoidable.
23 ... Ng4
24 Qxg4 Rf8+
25 Bf5  (25 Qf3?? Rxf3  26 gxf3 Qxf3+  27 Ke1 Qxh1+)
25 ... Rxf5+
26 Qxf5 gxf5

should be the way this got played, as two rooks vs a queen is pretty equal, especially when one rook is essentially stuck.
moves.23... Rf8 24. Bf5:
The only way to avoid a wicked loss.
After 24 ... gxf5, the game is lost for black with the material advantage of white.

24 ... Ng4 is still better than Ne4, since after 25 Qd4, 25 ... Kh6  26 Qxe3+ Nxe3+  27 Ke2 Nxd1, white only has a small positional advantage.
